sect1.title: Network Settings
sect1.para: The Networking Settings panel controls several global networking-related properties of your ⪚. Refer to the three subsections, , , and for more details.

sect2.title: Network Settings
sect2.para: The Network Settings Tab, as seen in , lets administrators control how their ⪚ appears to the outside (non-protected) network.

The ⪚ can be set-up to either have a static or dynamic IP address. For a static IP, administrators must configure the network settings as they would for any system on the network. Dynamic addresses are obtained from DHCP.

The interface for configuring these external settings is divided into three sections. The first section determines if the ⪚ is using a static or dynamic address. To choose between these options, the administrator selects either Automatically Set or Manually Set. If Automatically Set is selected, the ⪚ will use DHCP to obtain network settings and display them in the boxes below. If Manually Set is selected, the administrator must manually set the IP Address, Netmask, Default Route (sometimes referred to as gateway), as well as a primary DNS server and a secondary DNS server (optional).
Should Automatically Set be selected, then administrators can optionally request a renewal of their DHCP Lease via the Renew DHCP Lease button. This is the second section as seen in .

Whether Automatically Set or Manually Set is selected for the external interface, the Run Connectivity Test button can be used to perform a test of these settings. This is the third section as seen in . Activating the test will then report its findings (success/failure).

sect2.title: Email Settings
sect2.para: The Email Settings tab, as seen in , lets administrators control how ⪚ sends emails.

The ⪚ sends emails for several reasons. Various Software Appliances (for example, Virus Scanning) will send end-users emails informing them of malicious payloads such as viruses. The Quarantine feature sends users a daily digest of the spams they received, and the EdgeGuard Reports Appliance sends daily summary reports to administrators about their ⪚ activity.

The interface for configuring the email settings (as seen in ) requires two properties for normal mail traffic. The first property, Hostname, is the name of your SMTP mail server (e.g. mail.mycompany.com or 4.79.181.14). The second property is port. The standard port for sending email via SMTP is 25. You should only change this setting if you know your mail server is using a non-standard port.
For sites using authenticated SMTP (SMTP which requires a username and password), the Authentication Login and Authentication Password fields should be set. Otherwise, these can be safely left blank.
The final property, From Address, provides a FROM value for emails sent from ⪚.

sect2.title: Timezone
sect2.para: The Timezone for your ⪚ is set as seen in .
Administrators should select the timezone where the ⪚ is deployed.

sect2.title: Network Aliases
sect2.para: The Network Aliases tab, as seen in, , is for complex ⪚ deployments.

Use of this feature depends on if the ⪚ is providing NAT services to the internal (protected) network. If running NAT (see ), then this feature can be used to receive traffic for more than just the network of the ⪚'s external interface.
If your ⪚ is not running NAT (sometimes called bridge mode), then each addition to the Network Aliases will allow ⪚ to route traffic for networks other than that defined by its external IP address.
